advice.text: The most important aspect of your business is the people you serve. First we'll start by choosing an age group or two.
If you're not sure which age group you're going for, consider what sort of people tend to have the problem you're solving.
You can choose more than one; however, it's usually better to focus on as specific a group of people as possible.
Use the slider to choose a range of incomes. This helps determine what sort of lifestyle the people you're helping tend to have.

subQuestions.name: description
subQuestions.text: Describe this person in some detail, focusing on the challenge they have that you're solving.

advice.text: Try to get into their head and see the life, and therefore the problem they have, from their angle. What is it like for them to face this issue? What do they want to overcome?

questions.name: solution
questions.text: What solution do you offer to their challenge?

advice.text: Focus on how your product or service solves their problem. Try and describe the solution from their perspective.

Rather than describing the process or characteristics of your solution, talk about the result for the user or client. What do they get out of your solution? Always focus on them, rather than yourself.

questions.name: vision
questions.text: What is your vision for the brand?

advice.text: In an ideal world, if everything goes to plan, what will life be like for those whose problem you're solving?
Your vision for your brand is essentially what you're working towards. This is the reason you're doing all of this: to make something happen. What is that something?

examples.Google: To provide access to the world's information in one click.

questions.name: mission
questions.text: What is your mission? What are the steps you're taking to make your vision a reality?

advice.text: Your brand's mission entails the tangible means you're using to make your vision real. While your vision answers the question 'Why?', the mission answers the question 'How?'
Here are some great examples of mission statements (notice how they're more tangible and results-oriented than the vision statements above):

examples.Google: To organize the world's information and make it universally accessible and useful.

questions.name: style
questions.text: What visual message do you want to express to your future clients?

advice.text: Go with whatever style you feel fits you and your clients best. If there's nothing that goes exactly with what you have in mind, simply choose whatever's closest. You may choose more than one option.

Remember that the key here is to resonate with your clients, while still staying true and authentic to who you are. What aspect of your own style will connect with theirs? Also make sure you consider the actual product or service and the message that will make that the most appealing to them.

questions.text: How do you envision your business in 3 years? In other words, what your top 3 long-term business goals?

advice.text: Try and be as concrete as possible. Focus on goals that are quantifiable and measurable, like how many clients you'll have, desired revenue, breadth of reach, etc.

questions.text: What products do you need designed for your brand?

advice.text: Typical requirements include: visual identity (logo, colors, style guide), brand positioning (target market, user profiles, etc.), website, web and/or mobile app, ebook(s), pdf report(s), email marketing templates, etc.

questions.name: budget
questions.text: How much can you invest in your brand and online presence to jumpstart your business?

advice.text: While it may be difficult to specify an exact budget, use the slider to choose a rough range. This will help you create a more accurate action plan, and help us propose the best solution for you.
